Quotes Overheard from Bohnanza Pros

"If you gift me a Blue Bean now, I will surely gift you a Chili Bean later."

"Light diffraction is making my coin stack look larger than it really is. It's okay to trade with me!"

"Should I buy a third bean field? I dunno, CAN I buy a third bean field?"

"You gifted me a Coffee Bean because it ruins your setup, and I just drew Stink Bean and Wax Bean, both of which I need. PRO SKILL."

"What is that? A Garden Bean? That thing looks crazy! If I take this bean he will murder me while I sleep!"

Bohnanza is a game that is revered in my circles as a timeless classic, from the era where Uwe Rosenberg still designed fun things. And I've been convincing myself for years that I should love it, but when the time comes to pick any game in my library, I always pass on it. I think I'm now ready to part with my copy. Some disorganised notes:

• Complaints about the art style being fugly or the puns being cringe are really overstated. The words they're searching for are "charmingly old school cartoon".
• With the deterioration of my tryhard MTG habits, it's become easier to play games without reflexively shuffling my hand around. However, it turns out that this isn't that much easier for other people either, and the requirement to keep your hand in drawing order isn't really that easily followed by the general audience this game wants to reach.
• Bohnanza gets its reputation for being a strong negotiation game, but frankly there's very little exchanging of goodwill and future favours, and trades mostly happen when they're mutually beneficial in the optics of a short-term clock. The more flagship outlandish-sounding "I offer you 2 Saubohne in exchange for nothing" works as some lightbulb moment, but the fun of the absurdity has worn off by the end of the first session. I find it a great showcase piece for newcomers to modern tabletop games, but far less exciting on repeated plays.
• Scores and suit depletion are hidden trackable information, and the last stretch of the game really wants players to have forgotten who's currently ahead. Insert my usual grumbles.
• Without fail, after the second run through the deck, someone at the table who doesn't often play Bohnanza will let out "Wait, it's not over yet?".

Would always rather play Catan.

The main mechanic in this game is that you can't reorder your cards, you must play (plant your beans into your 2 fields) them in the order in which you drew them. But then you also put 2 open cards on the table every turn, which you can give away to other players if they aren't what you're looking for. There's definitely luck, but you can usually manage to make something out of it.

==================

Really tricky hand management rules. But once you get past internalising that rule, it is the best trading game I've played. The mechanics is better than Chinatown and Sideread Confluence. Chinatown is too random at early game and too predictable in the late game. Sidereal Confluence is pretty great, but it's hard to analyse the board state to figure out what people what - therefore, calculate how valuable your excess materials are.

Bohnanza is pretty stripped down trading. The planting mechanic gives players an incentive to sell. The board state isn't a bloody mess so you can actually read what people want. And the cards have different values, which makes the trade more complex than a simple 1 for 1 value.
A RIOT if played with the right people.

An excellent game, through and through. Honestly, it's only negative is that the bean puns that the German designers infused into each card doesn't translate very well at all. But that doesn't hinder play, in fact it's often a quirky topic of conversation.

75 kr

The trades are silly for how backwards they are in this game, but it works because it's player-driven. It's as crazy or tame as players want it to be. What slows it down is explaining all the weird procedure to a turn, do this then that, don't rearrange your hand. So maybe it's a miracle that it's as player-driven as it is. I find it more interesting than most euro trading games like Chinatown, maybe because of the possibility of things going disastrously wrong for a player.

Goodness, this one hasn't aged a bit, has it? Bohnanza provides fertile grounds for furious negotiations, but importantly, not constant negotiation. This, then, allows for something just as interesting: the meta-game that will emerge as a game progresses, and negotiations include those NOT bargaining for a particular deal, who will try to talk one side or the other out of the proposed deal. In few other games might you consider a trade that helps one player, is neutral to you, but is designed solely to deny a third player a crucial card.

The result is something magically cooperative AND cutthroat, where the rules are quickly internalized and the game immediately becomes an interpersonal decision space instead of a mechanical one.

This is also a game where player personalities come out, possibly more so than any other game I've played. Who you're playing with matters intimately, and that's true of the best games.

Various player counts present varying possible quibbles, but none bother me too much. This is really just Table Talk, The Game, and I love it for that.

Bohnanza shines for a few reasons...

1) It is light enough that it doesn't feel like work.

2) It has interesting decisions and tension

3) The presence of trading and the tension of fixed hand order means that you are engaged in the game on everyone else's turn (which is something most light traditional card games lack)

In Bohnanza, you can chat with people around the table and just have an overall relaxing yet engaging experience with your friends and family. This absolutely kills games like Uno and Phase 10. Once someone knows the rules, it doesn't feel that much harder. Yet it provides decisions, engagement, and it's not just blind luck!

The one downside of Bohnanza is it can be a little difficult to teach with non-gamers (the audience that this game shines with). If people give it a chance, they'll get it after once or twice around the table, but it's been a tough sell to even get people to try it in my experience
played this as a child. need a group of regulars for play to confirm my rating

Love the negotiating necessary for this game. One of the most satisfying games to teach to see when other players have the "a-ha moment."
All-timer!

You can play this game with anyone! And why you ask?
Trading and bartering is in our nature.. and this game shines in it.
Because of the way how you play you hand.. you need to trade or give away beans for free if you want the big bucks. Beans have worth, but because of the dynamic gameplay, this changes. How many of a certain bean are already out of the game? How much do I have in my hand? Are others going for the same beans?
You can play this cutthroath or casual.. social or to win.
It does not matter... you will have a very fun social experience!

This game is a winner! 10/10 Will never turn down a game of Bohnanza!
I can play this all my life. Easy, this is the best game on the geek. 4-5
Uno de los favoritos de la casa.

The perfect and easiest pure negotiation game. I'm always carrying it with me as it's a small box and has bring me so many good memories. To be fair i always run through the deck 2 times instead of 3 to keep the lenght great for a lean experience.
sleeved

Bohnanza my beloved. It's simply the best boardgame. I've showed this game to basically everyone I've played boardgames with, and everyone loves it. Multiple times people have bought it afterwards. Best in class negotiation and player interaction. Stupid theme and art that you will think is ugly and then come to love. The rules can be tricky to explain if you're not careful, but once you get the knack of it it'll be a 5 minute teach maximum. This can be a filler or it can be the main event. There's an element of luck involved but the best swindler always wins. The game's design guides you into trading in a fun way. You will want to give people good deals to get cards out of your hand, you will drive a hard bargain for the player who is in the lead and you will feel the sweet satisfaction of harvesting 3 garden beans. The German smallest box edition is superior because the bean names are funny to say and no one needs the coffee or a big box. I will never turn down a game of Bohnanza, everyone should own this.

Amazing classic card game that requires very little from players other than enthusiasm and the ability to have fun with the system and not take it too seriously. The negotiation is very freehanded and allows players to make deals that can be ludicrous and hilarious. It's been a hit at every single table I bring it to with people new to the hobby wanting to play repeat rounds or ask to borrow it.

Best at 5 players in my opinion.
